blog.name: aliceinsonderlust
blog.title: eclectic wanderlust
blog.description:
19 | new york | music student | bookworm | tea addict | chronic doodler

currently playing (primarily): beethoven’s pathetique sonata, mozart’s piano quartet in g minor (piano); bartok’s contrasts, third movement (clarinet)

currently reading: the master and margarita by mikhail bulgakov

summary: The pianist was unfortunately quite unextraordinary, though the orchestra he played with was phenomenal (first-rate horns and...
body: The pianist was unfortunately quite unextraordinary, though the orchestra he played with was phenomenal (first-rate horns and oboes in a non-professional community orchestra were a breathtaking surprise when they opened with a snippet of Swan Lake before the Rachmaninoff concerto). Mom was tired, so we left the concert at intermission and I got a bit of tea, switched from Gould to Rubinstein, and continued reading as though nothing happened.

reblog.comment: The pianist was unfortunately quite unextraordinary, though the orchestra he played with was phenomenal (first-rate horns and oboes in a non-professional community orchestra were a breathtaking surprise when they opened with a snippet of Swan Lake before the Rachmaninoff concerto). Additional Tags: Ineffable Husbands (Good Omens), Ineffable Godfathers, Sleepovers, Silly, Domestic, Scary Stories, Storytelling, Edgar Allan Poe References, Funny
Summary:

“Hmph. I suppose you think that, just because I’m an angel, that I’m too tame to read a scary story properly?”

I had this in the works for a few weeks now and am finally posting. This will be three chapters of ineffable silliness and it certainly helped me through writing my angst fic I still have in the works (ugh).

Enjoy!

tags: i know we've had some impressive adaptations like harry potter but come on. let's be honest
you cannot fit a 800 pages book into a 2 hours movie without sacrificing the story. you simply cannot
the only ones who ever came close were lord of the rings and i honestly still don't know how they pulled that off
summary: In defense of Game of Thrones
body:
In defense of Game of Thrones

With Game of Thrones ending in a couple of hours, I think we should collectively take time to reflect on how GoT revolutionised television. However you feel about it, I think we should be grateful to everything it’s done for story telling in television. Because honestly? Book adaptations had never really been done with that much effort and time put into it, spanning multiple years with multiple seasons.

Book were mostly solely adapted in movies, and while we had some fantastic book adaptations (LotR or Hunger Games), we can’t deny the impact Game of Thrones made on TV. Without it, I seriously doubt we would have had all the adaptations that we’ve had or will have.

Good Omens had been in talk for decades but it’s only ever been greenlit a couple of years ago. His Dark Materials had a mediocre movie adaptation that was so unfaithful to the entire work that the sequels were cancelled. Now we’ll have a (hopefully) full series ahead of us.

Game of Thrones really changed the way we look at book or comic adaptations and I’m extremely grateful to it for that. It’s opened so many doors and I can’t wait to see what lies beyond them.

blog.title: Good Omens
blog.description: Maintained by WhatJaneSays

summary: Silver and Gold
title: Silver and Gold
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2LVhiQa

by Veul_McLannon

Why did Mizpah (or remembrance) jewellery come back in bang around the turn of the century after being out of fashion for forty-odd years? Because Crowley woke up from his century-long nap, received a gift from his long-suffering companion and promptly ‘persuaded’ the local, very high-brow jeweller that they were in fashion again. Cheeky snake.

summary: List of things Newt does in the internet era
title: List of things Newt does in the internet era
body:
Breaks things.
Every computer he approaches malfunctions, and when he’s lucky enough to finally use one that doesn’t bluescreen, it always loads a 404 page not found error.

summary: List of things Anathema does in the internet era
title: List of things Anathema does in the internet era
body:
- is committed to at least 10 very specific blogs about witchcraft, astrology, body positivity, rock healing, future sight, feminism, ecology, etc 
- likewise, has subscriptions to a ton of newsletters and YT channels on these same topics
- believes every new conspiracy theory she comes accross ( most invented by Crowley )
- has furious arguments on Twitter and FB ( most initiated by Crowley ) 
- finds and shares recipes for home made cosmetics and natural healing stuff
- leaves aggressive comments on meninist pages and on “fake” litotherapy shops

blog.name: the-moon-loves-the-sea
blog.title: step by step we make our way
blog.description: Em, 31. Lesbian. // trans affirming fat positive queer joy // earth before country//

summary:
I truly think Aziraphale’s biggest temptation is to care too little, and Crowley’s is to care too much. 
Aziraphale would rather...
body:
I truly think Aziraphale’s biggest temptation is to care too little, and Crowley’s is to care too much.

Aziraphale would rather not get involved. He doesn’t want to ask questions, he doesn’t want to rebel, he doesn’t want anyone to panic even when panic is really warranted, he doesn’t want to have customers invading his happy place, he doesn’t want to pay attention to the fashions changing, he doesn’t want to have to bless people who aren’t on his way home. He can’t help caring when the problem’s right in front of him, but as soon as it’s out of his hands he tries to forget about it. He’s a pragmatist, more or less, in reaction I suppose to Heaven’s overweening idealism. In a world of horrible shining archangels he wants to be forgettable, and so left alone.

Meanwhile Crowley can’t stop himself getting involved. He questions everything; he doesn’t compose the smallest prank, or petty manipulation, without considering how to cause the least damage, and fall best in line with what people wanted to do anyway; he can’t let hell think he’s less than stellar, nor allow an angel to get disappointed in him even once; he needs to be cool. He needs to fix every little thing that goes wrong even when it is terribly clearly out of his hands. That might be a paranoid reaction to Hell’s demand for perfection, but I think it’s more likely his own rebellion against their cynicism. He will not be a pragmatist, not to their benefit; he demands a performance from himself that meets his ideals.

They are perfect for each other first because they love the world–but also because the angel needs someone to get him out of himself: to ask him out to lunch, and delight in his tiny rebellions, and get him involved in things with stakes, and force him to own his allegiances, and voice the questions he’s never risked admitting to. And the demon needs someone to help him calm down: to let him ramble, and tell him it will all work out, and steal his cake, and pour him more wine, and never once assess his performance, only notice and admire loudly and wholeheartedly the tender heart behind it.

reblog.comment:
I truly think Aziraphale’s biggest temptation is to care too little, and Crowley’s is to care too much.

Aziraphale would rather not get involved. He doesn’t want to ask questions, he doesn’t want to rebel, he doesn’t want anyone to panic even when panic is really warranted, he doesn’t want to have customers invading his happy place, he doesn’t want to pay attention to the fashions changing, he doesn’t want to have to bless people who aren’t on his way home. He can’t help caring when the problem’s right in front of him, but as soon as it’s out of his hands he tries to forget about it. He’s a pragmatist, more or less, in reaction I suppose to Heaven’s overweening idealism. In a world of horrible shining archangels he wants to be forgettable, and so left alone.

Meanwhile Crowley can’t stop himself getting involved. He questions everything; he doesn’t compose the smallest prank, or petty manipulation, without considering how to cause the least damage, and fall best in line with what people wanted to do anyway; he can’t let hell think he’s less than stellar, nor allow an angel to get disappointed in him even once; he needs to be cool. He needs to fix every little thing that goes wrong even when it is terribly clearly out of his hands. That might be a paranoid reaction to Hell’s demand for perfection, but I think it’s more likely his own rebellion against their cynicism. He will not be a pragmatist, not to their benefit; he demands a performance from himself that meets his ideals.

They are perfect for each other first because they love the world–but also because the angel needs someone to get him out of himself: to ask him out to lunch, and delight in his tiny rebellions, and get him involved in things with stakes, and force him to own his allegiances, and voice the questions he’s never risked admitting to. And the demon needs someone to help him calm down: to let him ramble, and tell him it will all work out, and steal his cake, and pour him more wine, and never once assess his performance, only notice and admire loudly and wholeheartedly the tender heart behind it.

tags: this is so silly i'm sorry
summary: ok, im quite bad at prompts, and its been a while since i last actually read good omens but if you wanna write something about...
question: ok, im quite bad at prompts, and its been a while since i last actually read good omens but if you wanna write something about crowley and aziraphale in the post-non-apocalyptic world of 2019? thatd be cool. or anything with adam, love that kid.
answer:
i was gonna do a serious fic for this but then i got mad and ended up writing about brexit, so…. sorry about that? but not really. it was fun.

Ever since the referendum the country’s been careening along like an out-of-control shopping trolley, rattling at a dangerous velocity towards – towards something. Whether it’s a good something or a bad something isn’t the point. At this stage, everyone is united in their desire to get the inevitable collision out of the way, just so they can start the cleanup process and get on with their lives.

He voices this idea to Crowley.

“Well, not really,” Crowley says, after giving it some thought. “I mean, yeah, don’t get me wrong, it’s a circus, I’m sick of it, you’re sick of it, we’re all sick of it. But I get the feeling that they’re rather enjoying themselves.”

Aziraphale shakes his head before Crowley’s even finished talking. “Enjoying themselves? No, no, that can’t be right. Haven’t you seen the television?”

“On occasion,” Crowley says, deadpan. 

“Then you know what I mean,” Aziraphale presses on. “All they ever seem to do is complain about the whole business, even the people who wanted it to happen in the first place.”

“But see, that’s exactly it. Humans love to complain about things,” Crowley says. “Just look at what they’re like with the weather. Something like this is practically a godsend, pardon my French – it means no matter how boring a conversation gets, there’s always a contentious topic handy to stir things up.”

Aziraphale revises his shopping-trolley analogy slightly. It’s not out of control per se, he decides. Rather, it’s being pushed downhill by some teenagers on a drunken bender, all of them whooping with delight as they mow down everything in their path.

“Ridiculous name, anyway,” he huffs. “Sounds like a kind of breakfast cereal.”

“I quite like it. Can’t fault a good portmanteau.”

Aziraphale sighs. “Perhaps we should be thankful for the grace period. You know what they say, falling’s not so bad – ”

“ – it’s the sudden stop at the end that gets you,” Crowley supplies, and grimaces. “Cheers. I hate that phrase.”

“I suppose you’d know,” Aziraphale muses.

“Yeah,” says Crowley, looking rather world-weary all of a sudden. “Suppose I would.”

summary: ‎David Tennant Does a Podcast With…: Michael Sheen on Apple Podcasts
body:
‎David Tennant Does a Podcast With…: Michael Sheen on Apple Podcasts

So for all of you, like me, awaiting Good Omens on May 31st I recommend this podcast with David Tennant interviewing Michael Sheen. It’s a treat and they talk about Good Omens, @neil-gaiman and lots of other fun stuff. 😁
